The electron temperature profile is computed by imposing the ideal gas law as expressed in Eq. (18).

Note that in \al@Arico2024, the ejected gas follows the temperature profile of the bound gas. In our preliminary analysis we found that this choice made it difficult for the model to match the amplitude of the matter–pressure power spectrum on large scales. We therefore set the temperature of the ejected gas independently using the Twsubscript𝑇wT_{\text{w}}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT parameter101010None that the Twsubscript𝑇wT_{\text{w}}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT parameter in our implementation is distinct from the Tfieldsubscript𝑇fieldT_{\text{field}}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT field end_POSTSUBSCRIPT parameter in \al@Arico2024, where the latter sets the temperature of the field component i.e., gas particles in an N-body simulation that are not associated with any halo. (analogous to the Twsubscript𝑇wT_{\rm w}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT parameter in the Mead20+ model).

Appendix B Measurements from simulations

B.1 Power spectrum

We use the Python library Pylians (Villaescusa-Navarro, 2018) to estimate the power spectrum from the particle data. We discretize the field onto a 3D grid with 10243 voxels using cloud-in-cell (CIC) mass assignment scheme. The default P⁢(k)𝑃𝑘P(k)italic_P ( italic_k ) measurements are in linearly spaced k𝑘kitalic_k-bins, with bin size equal to the fundamental model i.e., Δ⁢k=2⁢π/L=2⁢π/(640⁢h−1⁢Mpc)≈0.01⁢Mpc−1⁢hΔ𝑘2𝜋𝐿2𝜋640superscriptℎ1Mpc0.01superscriptMpc1ℎ\Delta k=2\pi/L=2\pi/(640\,h^{-1}{\rm Mpc})\approx 0.01\,{\rm Mpc}^{-1}hroman_Δ italic_k = 2 italic_π / italic_L = 2 italic_π / ( 640 italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Mpc ) ≈ 0.01 roman_Mpc start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h. To suppress the noise on large-scales, we re-bin all the measured power spectra in 100 uniformly linearly-spaced bins from k∼0.03−4⁢M⁢p⁢c−1⁢hsimilar-to𝑘0.034Mpsuperscriptc1ℎk\sim 0.03-4{\rm Mpc}^{-1}hitalic_k ∼ 0.03 - 4 roman_M roman_p roman_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h. All our power spectrum measurements are in comoving units.

When estimating the electron pressure power spectrum from the simulation we do not select gas particles that are at very low temperatures and are thus likely to comprise the cold neutral component. Specifically, we exclude gas particles with temperature <3×104absent3superscript104<3\times 10^{4}< 3 × 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT K and cold gas fraction >0.1absent0.1>0.1> 0.1 (Borgani et al., 2004). Although, we find that this choice has no impact on our measurements.

B.2 Halo profiles and mass fractions

To measure halo profiles, we first divide the halo population into four uniformly log-spaced mass bins spanning the range M200⁢c=1013−1015⁢h−1⁢M⊙subscript𝑀200csuperscript1013superscript1015superscriptℎ1subscriptMdirect-productM_{\rm 200c}=10^{13}-10^{15}\,h^{-1}{\rm M}_{\odot}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 200 roman_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 13 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊙ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We then use the halo catalog to randomly select 200 objects in each mass bin.

Radial profiles are measured in 16 logarithmically spaced bins from R=0.08−3⁢R200⁢c𝑅0.083subscript𝑅200cR=0.08-3\,R_{\rm 200c}italic_R = 0.08 - 3 italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 200 roman_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For the temperature profile, we compute the mass-weighted mean temperature of gas particles within each radial shell.

We also measure the bound gas and stellar mass fractions within R200⁢csubscript𝑅200cR_{\rm 200c}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 200 roman_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, defined as:

We compute the mean profiles (and mass fractions) in each mass bin as the average of all halos in the mass bin. When making model predictions for these quantities, we evaluate them at the same halo masses as the measurement and similarly obtain the average in a mass bin.

Appendix C Constraints on stellar fractions

In this appendix we present the inferred constraints on the stellar fractions, the results are presented in Figure 8. We find that all models underpredict the stellar content of halos, particularly at the high mass end, when only fitting to Rmmsubscript𝑅mmR_{\rm mm}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_mm end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Rmpsubscript𝑅mpR_{\rm mp}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_mp end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (left and middle panel). Including information about the gas distribution through Reesubscript𝑅eeR_{\rm ee}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ee end_POSTSUBSCRIPT significantly improves the inferred stellar fractions, bringing them into better agreement with simulation measurements (right panel).

Appendix D Fits to power spectra, mass fractions and thermodynamic profiles

In Sec. 6, we found that while all models accurately reproduce the power spectra and mass fractions, they fail to predict the thermodynamic profiles with similar precision. In this appendix, we test whether the models possess sufficient flexibility to converge to the correct solution when all the data are fit jointly.

Specifically, we fit (a) the power spectra of matter, pressure, and electron density; (b) the bound gas and stellar mass fractions, and (c) the radial profiles of electron pressure (𝒫esubscript𝒫e\mathcal{P}_{\rm e}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), temperature (Tesubscript𝑇eT_{\rm e}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), and density (ρesubscript𝜌e\rho_{\rm e}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). The fits are performed using the extended parameter set comprising 𝒪⁢(15)𝒪15\mathcal{O}(15)caligraphic_O ( 15 ) parameters (see Table 1). The likelihood contribution of the and mass fractions and power spectra is detailed in Sec. 5 (Eqs. 15 and 16, respectively).

We fit the profiles over the radial range xmin<r/r200⁢c≲1subscript𝑥min𝑟subscript𝑟200cless-than-or-similar-to1x_{\rm min}<r/r_{\rm 200c}\lesssim 1italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_r / italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 200 roman_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≲ 1, with xmin=0.25subscript𝑥min0.25x_{\rm min}=0.25italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.25 for group-mass halos and 0.12 for cluster-mass halos to maintain consistency in the sensitivity to physical scales probed in previous fits (Figs. 4, 5, 6, and 7). For all profiles we assume a measurement uncertainty σi⁢(r)=5subscript𝜎𝑖𝑟5\sigma_{i}(r)=5italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) = 5%.

The results are presented in Fig. 9. We find that the Schneider19+ model provides a reasonable match to all profiles across both mass bins. The power spectra and gas mass fractions are also fit with comparable accuracy to the previous cases where the profiles were not included in the fit. The Mead20+ and Arico24+ models similarly reproduce most quantities well, with the exception of the matter–pressure response, which is matched only at the 5–10% level. This suggests that these models are not flexible enough to simultaneously describe the halo profiles and power spectra. Note that all models fit the stellar mass fractions to within a few percent; these are therefore not shown.
